House Bill/Resolution NO. PS00038
FULL TITLE : MEASURES TO SOLVE THE PROBLEM OF LABOR CONTRACTING
SHORT TITLE : Labor - Only Contracting
ABSTRACT : Recognized by the Chair, Rep. Mark O. Go from the Lone District of Baguio City dealt with the issue of contractualization or the contracting out of work to independent contractors as against the prohibited labor-only contracting; the real situation of the ordinary Filipino workers; the difference between illegal and legal service contractors; the attempts in past Congresses to amend the pertinent provisions of the Labor Code on labor contracting and security of tenure of workers; and the current business and economic trends which tend to promote labor-only contracting but which should never jeopardize the rights, welfare and lives of Filipino workers. He then cited the following requirements and conditions that must be complied with if job contracting or outsourcing is to be allowed in the country; 1) not more than 10 to 20 percent of the total employees shall be contractual employees; 2) no employee should be terminated without just cause and due process as provided for in the Labor Code, within the period of his contract; 3) the right to self-organization shall be guaranteed; 4) provision for skill development and training must be established; and 5) the company engaged in outsourcing must be registered with the Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE). Finally, he urged his colleagues to support his proposed bill amending the Labor Code to arrive at a win-win situation both for the employees and employers. (SOURCE: House Journal No.10,p.21)
